contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox Officeholder | honorific-prefix = | name = John Herbert Turner | honorific-suffix = | image = John Herbert Turner.png | imagesize = | order = 11th | office = Premier of British Columbia | predecessor = [[Theodore Davie]] | successor = [[Charles Augustus Semlin]] | term_start = March 4, 1895 | term_end = August 8, 1898 | birth_date = {{birth date|1834|05|07}} | birth_place = [[Claydon, England]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1923|12|9|1834|05|07}} | death_place = [[Richmond, London|Richmond, England]] | nationality = | spouse = | party = | otherparty = | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = | occupation = | profession = | religion = | cabinet = }} '''John Herbert Turner''' (May 7, 1834 – December 9, 1923) was a [[British Columbia]] politician. Born in [[Claydon, Suffolk]], [[England]], Turner moved to [[British North America]] and worked as a merchant in [[City of Halifax|Halifax]] and [[Charlottetown]]. In 1862 he moved to [[Victoria, British Columbia]] and founded [[Turner, Beeton and Co.]] which was involved in salmon canning, insurance and finance, importing and wholesaling. He entered politics serving as [[mayor]] of Victoria from 1876 to 1881 and entered the provincial [[legislature]] in 1886 in the constituency of [[Victoria City (provincial electoral district)|Victoria City]]. He served as minister of finance under successive [[Premier]]s from 1887 to 1895 and as the [[List of Premiers of British Columbia|11th]] [[Premier of British Columbia|Premier of the province]] from 1895 to 1898. From 1901 to 1915 he was the province's representative in [[London]] where he retired.
